complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Break down the schema extension process into subtasks covering: (1) requirements gathering for new features, (2) detailed analysis of existing schema and relationships, (3) schema design for each new feature (notes, bookmarks, mind maps, sessions, AI conversations, content interactions), (4) drafting migration scripts, (5) peer review and documentation, (6) applying and testing migrations in staging, (7) validating data integrity and rollback procedures.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: Extending a production database schema to support multiple new interconnected features is complex, especially when integrating with existing tables and ensuring no redundancy or silos. Best practices require careful normalization, foreign key management, migration planning, and documentation[1][2][3][4]. Each new feature (notes, bookmarks, mind maps, etc.) may require its own schema changes and integration points, and robust testing is needed to ensure data integrity and maintainability.

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Expand into subtasks: (1) requirements and data source analysis, (2) design of aggregation logic, (3) implementation of content extraction from each source, (4) vector embedding integration, (5) full-text search setup, (6) metadata extraction and storage, (7) API/service interface design, (8) end-to-end testing and performance validation.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: Building a scalable, accurate content indexing service that aggregates from multiple sources, supports vector and full-text search, and integrates with existing infrastructure is highly complex. It involves data modeling, search technology, metadata management, and performance considerations, all of which require careful planning and modular implementation.
